items.description: River Lavant
items.message: The River Lavant is high, following a wet autumn. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and roads including at Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green in East Lavant. At The Sadlers in Westhampnett, the river will be high, but should remain lower than it has been over the past week. River flooding should not affect Chichester City Centre. The weekend will remain dry, however 15-20mm of rain is possible on Tuesday 19/12/2023. This could cause river levels to rise again and could potentially cause some minor flood impacts. The river will remain sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are operating the River Lavant Flood Alleviation Scheme to reduce the flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 17/12/2023.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Churn as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Today and overnight is forecast to be mainly dry. Tomorrow will see light rain in places, which will turn heavier overnight into Tuesday. Levels are expected to continue falling today and tomorrow, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels continue to fall, but please continue to take care around watercourses and low lying roads and lands. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue if necessary.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels are falling slowly, but remain high at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. 
Actual peak:- Llanymynech 4.22m Monday morning, 11/12/23. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message:
River levels remain high around Malton and Low Marishes due to recent persistent rainfall, but continue to fall slowly. Areas most at risk include low lying land around Low Marishes and Yedingham. River levels in Malton are expected to remain high for several days but are expected to continue falling. Pumping operations are ongoing in Malton and floodgates remain closed.
We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Sunday 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. River levels have fallen on the River Evenlode, but levels remain high and are slowly falling on the River Glyme near Woodstock. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the next few days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. We expect river levels to remain high and continue gradually falling over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Lower Dorset Frome but we have started to see levels falling in the last 48 hours. Levels at our Stinsford and East Stoke Gauges are falling slowly but this alert is likely to remain in force for at least the next 2 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for little to no rainfall for the next 3 days but rain is forecast to move in on Tuesday.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries due to the heavy rainfall in the last week and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. 
Levels around Salisbury are starting to fall slowly with levels at Fordingbridge forecast to peak today (Friday).
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is high, but now slowly falling. Flooding is still thought to be affecting land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the car park at Tesco on Shripney Road, fields near Shripney Lane, and be close to properties on Durban Road, Bersted. In Barnham, river levels have now fallen nearer to normal and any flood impacts should be minimal. The Aldingbourne Rife should continue to slowly fall however, flood impacts could remain until the middle of next week (20/12/2023). The weekend will remain dry, however 15-20mm of rain is possible on Tuesday 19/12/2023 which could cause river levels to rise again. Minor flood impacts could be possible in Barnham. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return nearer to normal until the new year. Water levels will remain sensitive to any additional rain in December. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 17/12/2023.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Saturday 16th December and for the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Barton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 17th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message:
River levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, the River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent prolonged rainfall. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area.

Levels are expected to stay high for several days but are expected to fall slowly. On Roam Drain, levels are still rising slowly with the areas most at risk including low lying land around Hempholme. We are operating pumps in the area. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00pm on Sunday 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high in the Lower Derwent catchment but continue to fall slowly. Flooding remains possible on low lying land, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. We expect levels to fall slowly over the coming days. No further significant rainfall is expected, but the catchment remains sensitive to additional rainfall. We continue to monitor levels closely. Continue acting on your flood plan and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4:00pm on Sunday 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries due to the heavy rainfall in the last week and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. 
Whilst levels are beginning to peak around Ringwood, Levels will remain high, above the Flood Alert level, for at least the next 3 days.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is dry for the next 3 days with further rain possibly moving in on Tuesday.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are currently falling on the River Leach as a result of recent rainfall. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Lechlade area. Today and overnight is forecast to be mainly dry. Tomorrow will see light rain in places which will turn heavier overnight into Tuesday. We expect river levels continue falling, today but levels may rise again in response to forecast rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks.
The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year but groundwater levels are currently declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are falling on the Chertsey Bourne after a period of previous heavy rain. No rainfall is forecast this weekend. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated in the morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels remain high but have fallen below the flood risk threshold. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in this area today, Saturday 16/12/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.04m and falling slowly. This level is being maintained by the water being pumped off the moor.

The pumping station drain level is 8.27m and falling steadily. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is expected when this level exceeds 8.35m. 

There is no rain forecast for Sunday. However, patchy showers are expected on Monday before a potentially heavier band of rain arrives early on Tuesday.

We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi pumping stations and will maximise pumping operations to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water.

Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent at Stamford Bridge but are now falling slowly. Flooding is expected to be affecting locations near the River Derwent with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Weir Caravan Park at Stamford Bridge and properties at Kexby Bridge. We expect levels to remain high into the weekend but to continue falling. We are monitoring river levels, managing flood defences, have pumps in operation and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Continue to act on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 4:00pm on Sunday 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
This flood alert has been removed. 

We are aware that specific locations are still impacted by flood water, namely the moors near Langport, Muchelney and Long Load. Information regarding these areas can be found via the Muchelney moors Flood Alert, which remains in force (/check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/target-area/112WAFYPM).

No property flooding is expected at this time and the situation is improving. There is no rain forecast for Sunday. However, patchy showers are expected on Monday before a potentially heavier band of rain arrives early on Tuesday.

River levels at Westover and Huish Episcopi stations remain high. Levels in the moors continue to fall steadily as pumping operations continue. We are monitoring the forecast and water-levels closely and will re-issue this alert if necessary. 

There are still significant low-lying areas of the Somerset moors affected by flooding. These will remain until water can be pumped or drain away naturally. Take care near rivers and flooded areas and dont put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since Friday 08/12/2023, 41mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End, and the groundwater level at Whitedale Farm has risen by 2.63m. Groundwater is currently affecting the cellars of a small number of properties on Lower West and East Street. The football pitch is also being affected by a mixture of sewage and groundwater. The weather from today (13/12/2023) until Sunday (17/12/2023) is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels in the village are expected to continue rising until the middle of next week. It is likely that more properties will be affected by cellar flooding on West Street and East Street during this time. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. Please remove any valuables from cellars, and if you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 08/12/2023, 36mm of rain has been recorded at Walderton, and the groundwater level in Finchdean has risen by 26cm. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are now flowing. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties in Finchdean. Over the next 5 days, the weather is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels in all villages are expected to rise for at least a week. In the next few days, it is possible that road flooding could begin to affect all villages, and cellar flooding could start to impact properties in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. Please remove valuables from cellars, and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/12/2023.

items.description: Tidal River Stour area from Fordwich to Stonar Cut
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The next high tide is forecast at Dover at 01:45 AM on 17/12/2023.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 01:30 AM and 04:30 AM on 17/12/2023.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Stour around Grove Ferry, Plucks Gutter and Stodmarsh.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

For information, the high tide at Dover will be 2.75mAOD

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.
The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries of the lower River Witham from Blankney to Sleaford

floodArea.riverOrSea: Kyme Eau, River Slea, Billinghay Skirth, Ruskington Beck, Old River Slea and Leasingham Beck

items.message: River levels remain high in the Blankney to Sleaford area following recent persistent rainfall. Further rainfall is not forecast for the next few days, however, we expect river levels to remain high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels are rising slowly on the Beverley and Barmston Drain and remain high on the River Hull due to recent rainfall, high groundwater levels and the effect of the tides. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including around Beverley and Dunswell, and the central River Hull area including Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell. No further significant rainfall is forecast, however river levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. We are in the area operating pumping stations and checking defences, aswell as operating flood defences across the wider catchment area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Sunday 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. There is no significant rainfall forecast over the next 48 hours.

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 17/12/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Willington and Shardlow river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Ingleby, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Areas also at risk include the B5008 at Willington, the access frontage at Swarkestone, the A5132 between Willington and Barrow, and Meadow Lane.

No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until the weekend.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.   No further rainfall is forecast. 

We continue to monitor the situation. 

Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Bredon river gauge. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning. 
Peaks:- Evesham peaked at 2.30m on 10/12/23, and Bredon peaked at 2.7m on 11/12/23. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels continue to fall in the Upper Stour and will continue to do so over the next couple of days, River levels are at the top of normal range but are reducing at Chart Leacon.

The risk of flooding is reducing. Please take care using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
We continue to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater
items.message: River levels remain high in the Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater area following recent persistent rainfall. Further rainfall is not forecast for the next few days, however, we expect river levels to remain high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.28m and falling slowly. This level is being maintained by the water being pumped off the moor. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor is currently 5.94m and falling steadily in response to pumping operations.

There is no rain forecast for Sunday. However, patchy showers are expected on Monday before a potentially heavier band of rain arrives early on Tuesday.

We are currently pumping at Currymoor, Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and will maximise pumping operations to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. We will continue to monitor all river and moor levels closely, and our staff are checking flood defences.

Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water.

This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
Weymouth Rivers and Streams
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Wey, Preston Brook, River Jordan following recent rainfall and additional contribution to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Levels at our Broadway gauge are starting to slowly fall but are likely to remain above the flood alert level for at least the next 3 days.

The forecast is generally dry until Tuesday when rain may return.

Flooding is possible at the River Wey to Radipole Lake, Preston Brook and River Jordan.

We are monitoring river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 16:00 on 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Windrush. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Newbridge area. Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. River levels have fallen in the upper reaches. Levels remain high at Newbridge but have begun slowly falling.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Sandhurst river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall and the tidal influence of the Severn Estuary. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 
Mythe peaked at, 3.99m on 14/12/23, Haw Bridge, peaked at 5.1m on 14/12/23, Sandhurst, 3.3m to 3.5m at 12:30 am on 17/12/2023 and 3.1m to 3.3m at 12:45pm Sunday 17/12/2023 during high tides. Gloucester, 3.1m to 3.3m at 12:15 am on 17/12/2023 and 3.0m to 3.2m at 12:15pm Sunday 17/12/2023, during high tides. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
Kempsey Village
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is now operating. 
Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 6.2m on 14/12/23. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Worcester river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke and Upton upon Severn. Install Property level protection if required. 
Peaks:- Bewdley peaked at 3.35m on 15/12/2023, Worcester peaked at 4.38m on 14/12/2023 and Diglis, peaked at 4.15m on 14/12/2023, Kempsey Yacht Club, peaked at 6.2m on 14/12/2023, and Saxons Lode, peaked at 4.73m on 14/12/2023. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Holderness Drain

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: Winestead Drain, Holderness Drain, Burstwick Drain, Skeffling Drain, Long Bank Drain, Keyingham Drain, Old Fleet Drain, Kellwell Stream, Lambwath Stream

items.message: River levels continue to fall, but please continue to take care around watercourses and low lying roads and lands. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue if necessary.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels in the Upper River Hull catchment remain high due to recent persistent rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill. River levels are expected to remain high for several days and we are operating pumps in the area. We continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action, avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4:00pm on Sunday 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ock from Watchfield to Abingdon, and also the Letcombe Brook at Wantage, Grove and East Hanney
items.message:
This flood alert has been removed. 
The recorded rise in river levels occurred due to a fault at the Stanford Vale river gauge. Our staff have been to the location this morning to remove blockages and confirm river levels are within banks.
Today and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. River levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. 
Mythe peaked at 3.99m on 14/12/23. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 18/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels have fallen. The forecast is for no further rainfall until Tuesday, 19/12/23, when there is a possibility of high rainfall totals. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 7am on 17/12/23. The causeway at Earith may have some water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 56cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney currently has approximately 72cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 4pm today, 17/12/23.

items.description: Lower River Witham
items.message: River levels remain high in the Lower Witham area following recent persistent rainfall. Further rainfall is not forecast for the next few days, however, we expect river levels to remain high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Apperley and The Leigh
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding may be affecting Gabb Lane at Apperley and local caravan parks. 
Haw Bridge peaked at 4.93m 15/12/23. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Lower Nene
items.message: River levels remain high in the Lower Nene area following recent persistent rainfall. Further rainfall is not forecast over the next few days, however, we expect river levels to remain high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed and no property flooding is expected. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. Flood water will still be present, affecting roads and low-lying land.

No rain is forecast for Saturday and Sunday. Monday is expected to be largely dry before a band of potentially heavy rain arrives on Tuesday.

The river level in the Tone remains high but is being maintained at this level due to the water being pumped off the moor. We expect the Currymoor drain level to continue falling steadily while the  pumping operations, dry weather and river level allows.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and water-levels, and will re-issue this warning if necessary. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
There will still be areas where flood water is present until it can either be pumped into the river or drain away naturally.

items.description: River Trent at Girton
items.message: River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for this area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  We continue to monitor the situation. There is no significant rainfall forecast over the next 48 hours.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured in October, November and December 2023. Groundwater is high, within a few centimetres of the surface in East Dean, and still rising. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with springs appearing, water flowing on roads, water in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. A small amount of water could also flow down the B2141 at Chilgrove. Very little rainfall is forecast for the next five days, however groundwater will continue rising until at least 17/12/2023 at the Chilgrove borehole. Flood impacts are expected to remain until at least the middle of January, and potentially longer or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 20/12/2023

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels remain high in the Heighington to Dunston area following recent persistent rainfall. Further rainfall is not forecast for the next few days, however, we expect river levels to remain high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area where there is still flooding to roads and low lying land. We do not expect any further flooding to properties at this time.

There is no rain forecast for Sunday. However, patchy showers are expected on Monday before a potentially heavier band of rain arrives early on Tuesday.

The River Yeo remains high. The level in the Huish Episcopi Main Drain is falling steadily as pumping operations continue. We are monitoring the forecast closely and will re-issue this warning if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message: River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for this area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  We continue to monitor the situation. There is no significant rainfall forecast over the next 48 hours.

items.description: River Trent at Collingham
items.message: River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for this area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  We continue to monitor the situation.  There is no significant rainfall forecast over the next 48 hours

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels at all sites in West Dorset remain very high. It is likely that some roads will be flooded in the North and South Winterbourne, Hooke, Sydling, Cerne and Piddle valleys. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should deploy them now. Communities to the east of Dorchester are now at risk.  Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent property and may put your own and emergency responders lives at risk. This message will be updated on Thursday14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Hooke
items.message:
The Groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has eased back slightly to 167.8m above sea level following a very rapid rise at the end of last week. With a drier spell forecast for the week ahead, conditions should see a slight improvement, although patches of standing water will remain on roads for several days ahead. Drivers are asked to slow down when driving through even shallow water as the bow wave can cause damage to nearby properties. Driving more slowly reduces the chance that water will enter your engine, which, if it happens can cause the engine to be written off. Check that pumps and other property level resilience measures are still working correctly, and perhaps think about contingency measures should they fail.
We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in your area and this message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at Kingston Russell borehole has risen once more, although the rate of rise is now slowing. The level at 121.36m above sea level is the highest ever recorded at this location, however as this has been achieved over several weeks the impact will be less severe than on previous occasions, such as in 2012, when a similar level was reached within just a few days. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should ensure that they are operating correctly and should make contingency plans against their failure. 
Avoid driving through flood water as  this can put your life and that of emergency responders at risk. The bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Thursday the 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cerne Valley
items.message:
The Groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has eased back slightly to 167.8m above sea level following a very rapid rise at the end of last week. With a drier spell forecast for the week ahead, conditions should see a slight improvement, although patches of standing water will remain on roads for several days ahead. Drivers are asked to slow down when driving through even shallow water as the bow wave can cause damage to nearby properties. Driving more slowly reduces the chance that water will enter your engine, which, if it happens can cause the engine to be written off. Check that pumps and other property level resilience measures are still working correctly, and perhaps think about contingency measures should they fail.
We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in your area and this message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Sydling
items.message:
The Groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has eased back slightly to 167.8m above sea level following a very rapid rise at the end of last week. With a drier spell forecast for the week ahead, conditions should see a slight improvement, although patches of standing water will remain on roads for several days ahead. Drivers are asked to slow down when driving through even shallow water as the bow wave can cause damage to nearby properties. Driving more slowly reduces the chance that water will enter your engine, which, if it happens can cause the engine to be written off. Check that pumps and other property level resilience measures are still working correctly, and perhaps think about contingency measures should they fail.
We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in your area and this message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Devils Brook
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down borehole have fallen back slightly overnight to 167.8 metres above sea level whilst the level at nearby Doles Ash has risen 10cm to 122.91 metres. Levels at both are expected to drop back over the next week in line with the forecast drier spell. Many local roads will be flooded for sometime and motorists are asked to drive slowly through these as the bow wave created by vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. Driving slowly reduces the risk of water being taken up into the engine. Sewage systems are are likely to be impacted for some time. This message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Doles Ash borehole have risen to 122.91 metres above sea level. Some property flooding as well as disruption to the road and sewer networks is expected, however, as a spell of drier weather moves in over the next week, conditions may show a slight improvement.  Home owners with property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should check that they are working correctly, and consider what contingency measures that they could employ in the event of a failure. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties. Stay out of flood water which is hazardous to you and emergency service staff who may have to rescue you. This message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 16th December 2023. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 17th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are gradually falling on the River Dikler. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Bourton On The Water area. Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling slowly on the Ginge Brook, although the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Steventon area. Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. River levels are expected to continue falling over the next few days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured in October, November and December 2023. Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but stable at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will continue, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. It is not expected to rain again before Tuesday 19/12/2023, however the weather forecast remains uncertain. Groundwater is expected to stabilise then fall by a few centimetres at the Compton borehole, from 17/12/2023. Wednesday, Thursday and Friday look mild with the chance of more wet weather, which could cause groundwater to rise again. Groundwater will remain higher than normal, sensitive to any additional rainfall, with risk of flood over the winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 20/12/2023

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but falling on the lower River Kennet as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Theale area. Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. We expect river levels to continue falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are falling on the Thames after a period of previous heavy rain. No rainfall is forecast this weekend. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated in the morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured in October, November and December 2023. Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Ladies Mile borehole. It is unlikely, but minor groundwater flood impacts might still be possible, as it takes a few days for groundwater to travel from Ladies Mile. Water could appear in a small number of basements by 20/12/2023. Previous impacts initially affected Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. It is not expected to rain again before Tuesday 19/12/2023, however the weather forecast is uncertain. Groundwater at Ladies Mile should fall through to Wednesday 20/12/2023. Mild and wet weather looks possible at times next week, which could cause groundwater to rise again. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 20/12/2023

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels remain high in the Peterborough area following persistent rainfall.  During periods of high tide the river Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions.  Whilst this flood warning remains in force, the local authority will close North Bank Road and diversionary routes will be in place and further updates will be available through the local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels remain high in the Peterborough area following persistent rainfall. This Flood Warning is expected to stay in force over the coming days, until water levels recede. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.  We are closely monitoring the situation, and this message will be updated by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at all sites across the Chase have continued to rise overnight. Flooding of minor roads across the area is expected, with the Upper Tarrant valley, The Gussage at Minchington 
 and the road across Wyke Down to Monkton up Wimborne worst affected. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should deploy them now. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent property and may put your own and emergency responders lives at risk. This message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A series of high tides is expected over the next few days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted Peaks: Sandhurst, 3.3m to 3.5m at 12:30 am on 17/12 and 3.1m to 3.3m at 12:45pm Sunday 17/12 during high tides. Gloucester, 3.1m to 3.3m at 12:15 am on 17/12 and 3.0m to 3.2m at 12:15pm Sunday 17/12, during high tides. 
Flooding is not currently expected in other gauge locations. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. 
This message will be updated by 1pm on Sunday, 17/12/2023, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are gradually falling on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. The risk of  flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Goring area. Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. We expect river levels to continue gradually falling over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high but starting to recede at the Salisbury Bourne river gauge on the River Bourne due to the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Levels at our Ebbesbourne Wake and Salisbury gauges are receding but remain high. This Alert is likely to remain in place for the next 5 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is currently for dry weather for the next 3 days with rain possible on Tuesday.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (322mm) was recorded in Andover. At Clanville Gate, the rate of rise is slow, at 10cm per day. We expect groundwater to be impacting the sewer network at Penton Mewsey and the main road at Penton Grafton is expected to be impacted by flooding within the next few days. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. It is possible that a very small number of cellars will be affected in Appleshaw from Friday 15/12/2023. From Wednesday 13/12/2023 to Monday 18/12/2023 the weather is expected to become drier, however we expect levels to continue to rise for at least the next 7 days. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables stored in cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (381mm) was recorded at our rain gauge in Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level has increased by 19cm. At the current rate of rise, cellar flooding is possible from Thursday 14/12/2023 at the southern end of the village at South End Close. From Saturday 16/12/2023, cellar flooding could occur at the Dolphin Inn Pub and impacts to the sewage network could be experienced. From Wednesday 13/12/2023 to Monday 18/12/2023 the weather is expected to be drier, however levels are still expected to rise for at least another week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated at 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  No further rainfall is forecast. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, north of the A354
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have risen following the current period of prolonged rainfall. Some property flooding as well as disruption to the road and sewer networks is expected. Home owners with property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should check that they are in place and working properly. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties. Stay out of flood water which is hazardous to you and emergency service staff who may have to rescue you. This message will be updated on Friday 15th or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Pangbourne to Purley
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
Overnight and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
The next high tide is not forecast to overtop banks and flood low lying land. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  No further rainfall is forecast. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (451mm) was recorded in Warnford. The winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for several weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. The weather from today (13/12/2023) until Sunday (17/12/2023) is forecast to be dry. At our borehole at Pound Lane, the groundwater level will stabilise by Friday 15/12/2023, before beginning to slowly fall. Long range forecasting is difficult, but there is currently an indication that unsettled weather will return to Hampshire from the end of next week. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will rise again, and water will begin flowing across Rectory Lane. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding south of the Humber Estuary
items.message: Over the past few weeks we have seen heavy and prolonged rainfall across North Lincolnshire. This will lead to continued flooding of low lying land from today Saturday 16 December onwards. Impacts are expected for several days, or weeks. Groundwater flooding can be distinguished from river flooding as it will often be clear and is unlikely to flow. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 11:00 on 17 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at many of the boreholes used for Flood Warnings on Salisbury Plain and in the Vale of Wardour have risen following 12 weeks of above average rainfall. Despite a brief spell of drier weather groundwater levels will continue to rise over the next few days. Further rainfall, perhaps as much as 20mm is expected on Tuesday next week. 
Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should deploy them now.
It is likely that some roads will be flooded, particularly in the Dene, Fonthill, Teffont, Till, Wylye, Woodford  and Chitterne valleys. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent property and may put your own and emergency responders lives at risk. 
This message will be updated on Saturday the 16th December or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ock at Longcot, Stanford in the Vale, Charney Bassett, Lyford and Garford
items.message:
This flood warning has been removed. 
The recorded rise in river levels occurred due to a fault at the Stanford Vale river gauge. Our staff have been to the location this morning to remove blockages and confirm river levels are within banks.
Today and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry, with the potential for light rainfall in places. River levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. We continue to monitor the situation.
